intro: Fagara articulata, commonly known as the segmented cowcalf, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of Central and South America. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae, which includes over 13,000 species of flowering plants. The plant is characterized by its compound leaves with elliptical leaflets and clusters of small, white to pale yellow flowers. Its fruit is a globose, fleshy berry that contains several seeds. Fagara articulata is often found in moist, shaded habitats such as forest understories.
